llm_metadata_harvester.cheatsheet module

llm_metadata_harvester.checks module

llm_metadata_harvester.checks.check_exist(extracted_metadata: dict, raw_input: str, threshold: float = 0.8) → dict[str, bool][source]

Check if metadata value exist in raw input using fuzzy matching.

For each value in extracted_metadata this does a fuzzy substring match against raw_input. Returns a tuple of booleans for each metadata value.

llm_metadata_harvester.checks.check_repeat_prompt(extracted_metadata: dict, metadata_definition: dict, threshold: float = 0.8) → dict[str, bool][source]

Check if the metadata values are repeating the prompt.

llm_metadata_harvester.harvester_operations.chunk_text(text: str, llm: LLMClient, max_tokens: int = 6000) → list[str][source]

Split text into chunks that fit within token limit

llm_metadata_harvester.harvester_operations.extract_entities(text: str, meta_field_dict: dict = None, llm: LLMClient = None, source_url: str = '', return_initial_result: bool = False) → dict | Tuple[dict, dict][source]

Extract entities and relationships from text using LLM. :param text: The input text to process. :type text: str :param meta_field_dict: Dictionary of metadata fields to extract. :type meta_field_dict: dict :param llm: The LLM client to use for entity extraction. :type llm: LLMClient :param source_url: Optional URL for the source of the text. :type source_url: str :param return_initial_result: If True, return both initial and cleaned nodes. :type return_initial_result: bool

async llm_metadata_harvester.harvester_operations.metadata_harvest(model_name: str, url: str, metadata_standard: dict = {'Access rights': 'Information about who can access the resource or an indication of its security status.\nWays in which the dataset may or may not be accessed and used.', 'Data contact point': 'Relevant contact information for the cataloged resource. Use of vCard is recommended\n[VCARD-RDF]. Make sure to include the full name of the contact person/institution and their email address.', 'Data creator': 'An entity that brought into existence the dataset being described. Creators can be people,\norganizations and/or physical or virtual infrastructure (e.g., sensors, software).', 'Data publisher': 'The entity responsible for making the resource available. Resources of type foaf:Agent\nare recommended as values for this property.', 'Description': 'Provide detailed information about the dataset, typically at the level of an abstract.\nBe sure to include the entire abstract text, not just a portion of it.', 'Distribution access URL': 'A URL of the resource that gives access to a distribution of the dataset.\nE.g., landing page, feed, SPARQL endpoint.\ndcat:accessURL SHOULD be used for the URL of a service or location that can provide access to this\ndistribution, typically through a Web form, query or API call.\ndcat:downloadURL is preferred for direct links to downloadable resources.\nIf the distribution(s) are accessible only through a landing page (i.e., direct download URLs are not\nknown), then the landing page URL associated with the dcat:Dataset SHOULD be duplicated as access URL\non a distribution (see 5.7 Dataset available only behind some Web page).', 'Distribution byte size': "The size of a distribution in bytes. The size in bytes can be approximated (as\na non-negative integer) when the precise size is not known. While it is recommended that the size be\ngiven as an integer, alternative literals such as '1.5 MB' are sometimes used.", 'Distribution format': 'An established standard to which the dataset distribution conforms to. The file\nformat of the distribution.  dcat:mediaType SHOULD be used if the type of the distribution is defined\nby IANA [IANA-MEDIA-TYPES].', 'Keywords': 'Concepts (keywords, classification, or free text terms) that define the dataset or purpose\n(subjects which can be addressed) using the dataset.', 'Landing page': 'A Web page that can be navigated to in a Web browser to gain access to the catalog,\ndataset, its distributions and/or additional information.', 'License': 'A legal document under which the resource is made available. Text string describing any rights\ninformation for the dataset being described.', 'Metadata date': 'This element contains the date on which the metadata was created or updated. The\ndate format is YYYY-MM-DD (with hyphens).', 'Metadata language': 'Language in which the dataset being described is provided. It contains\nthe code of the language used in the metadata text. Only the three-letter codes from ISO 639-2/B\n(bibliographic codes) should be used, as defined in ISO 639-2. The code for Dutch is "dut".', 'Resource type': 'The nature or genre of the resource. The value SHOULD be taken from a well governed\nand broadly recognised controlled vocabulary, such as:\n    DCMI Type vocabulary [DCTERMS]\n    [ISO-19115-1] scope codes\n    Datacite resource types [DataCite]\n    PARSE.Insight content-types used by re3data.org [RE3DATA-SCHEMA] (see item 15 contentType)\n    MARC intellectual resource types\nSome members of these controlled vocabularies are not strictly suitable for datasets or data\nservices (e.g., DCMI Type Event, PhysicalObject; [ISO-19115-1] CollectionHardware, CollectionSession,\nInitiative, Sample, Repository), but might be used in the context of other kinds of catalogs defined\nin DCAT profiles or applications.', 'Responsible organization metadata': 'This element contains the name of the organization responsible\nfor the metadata. Use the full written name of the responsible organization. An abbreviation may\nbe added to the organization name. For correct official government organization names, refer to\nthe list of government organizations. Preferably, fill in this element as a gmx:Anchor, where the\nhref attribute points to a URI that describes the organization.\nExample: source:\n    <Anchor\n    xlink:href="https://www.tno.nl/nl/over-tno/organisatie">\n        Nederlandse organisatie voor\n        toegepast-natuurwetenschappelijk onderzoek (TNO)\n    </Anchor>\nresult: Nederlandse organisatie voor toegepast-natuurwetenschappelijk onderzoek (TNO).', 'Spatial coverage': 'The geographical area covered by the dataset. The spatial coverage of a dataset may be\nencoded as an instance of dcterms:Location, or may be indicated using an IRI reference (link) to a\nresource describing a location. It is recommended that links are to entries in a well maintained\ngazetteer such as Geonames.', 'Spatial reference system': 'This element contains the Alphanumeric value that indicates the reference system\nused for the dataset. EPSG issues these codes. For the RD, the code 28992 is used. The reference system\nis included with a URI that also contains the code.\nExample: source:\n    <gmx:Anchor\n    xlink:href="http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/EPSG/0/28992">RD\n    </gmx:Anchor>\nresult: http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/EPSG/0/28992', 'Spatial resolution': 'Minimum spatial separation resolvable in a dataset, measured in meters. If the\ndataset is an image or grid this should correspond to the spacing of items. For other kinds of spatial\ndatasets, this property will usually indicate the smallest distance between items in the dataset.', 'Temporal coverage': 'The temporal period that the dataset covers. An interval of time that is named or\ndefined by its start and end dates.', 'Temporal resolution': 'Minimum time period resolvable in the dataset. If the dataset is a time-series this\nshould correspond to the spacing of items in the series. For other kinds of dataset, this property will\nusually indicate the smallest time difference between items in the dataset.', 'Title': 'A name given to the resource.', 'Unique Identifier': 'A unique identifier of the resource being described or cataloged. The identifier\nis a text string which is assigned to the resource to provide an unambiguous reference within a\nparticular context.'}, dump_format: str = 'none', allow_retrying: bool = False) → dict[source]

Harvest metadata wrapper function. First extract full text from URL, then extract entities using LLM, finally convert nodes to metadata dictionary. If allow_retrying is True, perform checks and retry extraction for missing fields. A hile loop is used to continue retrying until all fields are extracted. If dump_format is specified, dump metadata to file.

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.compute_mdhash_id(content: str, prefix: str = '') → str[source]

Compute a unique ID for a given content string.

The ID is a combination of the given prefix and the MD5 hash of the content string.

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.limit_async_func_call(max_size: int)[source]

Add restriction of maximum concurrent async calls using asyncio.Semaphore

Split a string by multiple markers

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.clean_str(input: Any) → str[source]

Clean an input string by removing HTML escapes, control characters, and other unwanted characters.

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.is_float_regex(value: str) → bool[source]
llm_metadata_harvester.utils.truncate_list_by_token_size(list_data: list[Any], key: Callable[[Any], str], max_token_size: int) → list[int][source]

Truncate a list of data by token size

async llm_metadata_harvester.utils.use_llm_func_with_cache(input_text: str, use_llm_func: callable, llm_response_cache: BaseKVStorage | None = None, max_tokens: int = None, history_messages: List[Dict[str, str]] = None, cache_type: str = 'extract') → str[source]

Call LLM function with cache support

If cache is available and enabled (determined by handle_cache based on mode), retrieve result from cache; otherwise call LLM function and save result to cache.

Parameters:

  • input_text – Input text to send to LLM

  • use_llm_func – LLM function to call

  • llm_response_cache – Cache storage instance

  • max_tokens – Maximum tokens for generation

  • history_messages – History messages list

  • cache_type – Type of cache

Returns:

LLM response text

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.get_content_summary(content: str, max_length: int = 250) → str[source]

Get summary of document content

Parameters:

  • content – Original document content

  • max_length – Maximum length of summary

Returns:

Truncated content with ellipsis if needed

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.normalize_extracted_info(name: str, is_entity=False) → str[source]

Normalize entity/relation names and description with the following rules: 1. Remove spaces between Chinese characters 2. Remove spaces between Chinese characters and English letters/numbers 3. Preserve spaces within English text and numbers 4. Replace Chinese parentheses with English parentheses 5. Replace Chinese dash with English dash

Parameters:

name – Entity name to normalize

Returns:

Normalized entity name

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.clean_text(text: str) → str[source]

Clean text by removing null bytes (0x00) and whitespace

Parameters:

text – Input text to clean

Returns:

Cleaned text

llm_metadata_harvester.utils.node_2_metadata(clean_nodes: dict) → dict[source]

Dump metadata to a JSON/YAML file, creating directories if necessary.

llm_metadata_harvester.webutils module

llm_metadata_harvester.webutils.readWebContent(url: str) → BeautifulSoup[source]

Reads the content of a webpage and returns a BeautifulSoup object. :param url: The URL of the webpage to read. :return: A BeautifulSoup object containing the parsed HTML content.

llm_metadata_harvester.webutils.downloadAndParseXML(url)[source]

Downloads metadata XML from the Wadden data service and parses it. Params: url (str): The URL of the XML to download. Returns: tuple: (xml_str, root) where xml_str is the raw XML text and root is the parsed ElementTree root

async llm_metadata_harvester.webutils.extract_full_page_text(url: str) → str[source]

Asynchronously extracts all visible text content from a web page.

This function uses Playwright to launch a headless Chromium browser, navigate to the specified URL, scrolls to the bottom of the page to ensure lazy-loaded content is displayed, and then retrieves all inner text from the page’s body.

Parameters:

url – The URL of the webpage to read.
